content.body: It's rather trivial to write a wrapper for an iterator that doesn't forward `return`
content.formatted_body: It's rather trivial to write a wrapper for an iterator that doesn't forward return

content.body: (and they consider this best practice in general)
We will return in one hour.  If any of the remote attendees have feedback on AV etc please say it here.
I find "limit" less understandable than "take". If it helps avoid misunderstanding, I would expect that's only because one has to read the docs to understand what it does at all.

imo "limit" conveys very clearly that the iterator is closed, i guess because it sounds like SQL limit, and obviously SQL queries are not stateful; whereas "take" is much more ambiguous. but i guess this is a minority view!
Are there actually any iterator helpers in the proposal that do *not* close the underlying iterator?
content.formatted_body: Are there actually any iterator helpers in the proposal that do not close the underlying iterator?

content.body: They all either iterate everything (thus closing the underlying), or close when they early exit
`take` is special in that `take` ends _before_ exhausting the underlying iterator
content.formatted_body: take is special in that take ends before exhausting the underlying iterator

content.body: My general expectation is that if I pass an iterator off to any other code, I should assume it is exhausted and not touch it again myself.
whereas if you `map` or something the expectation is that it either you are exhausting it, which will naturally close the underlying iterator, or closing the `map` helper explicitly
content.formatted_body: whereas if you map or something the expectation is that it either you are exhausting it, which will naturally close the underlying iterator, or closing the map helper explicitly

content.body:
> <@bakkot:matrix.org> `take` is special in that `take` ends _before_ exhausting the underlying iterator

So does `some`, `every`, and `find`
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @bakkot:matrix.org
take is special in that take ends before exhausting the underlying iterator
So does some, every, and find

content.body: Justin Ridgewell: those don't produce new iterators though
content.formatted_body: Justin Ridgewell: those don't produce new iterators though

content.body: Caveat being that `some`, `every`, and `find` return scalar results
content.formatted_body: Caveat being that some, every, and find return scalar results

content.body: they are as it were "consumers" rather than "transfomers"
Though `take` ending before exhausting the iterator is a misconception. The fact it calls `return` is more of an optimization than a meaningful difference when it comes to sequence operators.
content.formatted_body: Though take ending before exhausting the iterator is a misconception. The fact it calls return is more of an optimization than a meaningful difference when it comes to sequence operators.

content.body: by "an optimization", do you mean relative to the option of manually exhausting the underlying by calling `.next` repeatedly, or something else?
content.formatted_body: by "an optimization", do you mean relative to the option of manually exhausting the underlying by calling .next repeatedly, or something else?

content.body: Yes.
If JS had no `.return` and the only way to close an iterator were to exhaust it, I would expect `take` to exhaust the iterator.
content.formatted_body: If JS had no .return and the only way to close an iterator were to exhaust it, I would expect take to exhaust the iterator.

content.body: So its good that `return` exists, as it allows us to short-circuit such an expensive operation.
content.formatted_body: So its good that return exists, as it allows us to short-circuit such an expensive operation.

content.body: But I'm pretty sure that in every example of prior art in the ecosystem, where `take` is used it means "take X items and exhaust/close the underlying iterator"
content.formatted_body: But I'm pretty sure that in every example of prior art in the ecosystem, where take is used it means "take X items and exhaust/close the underlying iterator"

content.body: If the iterator were a database, I would expect `take` to close the connection when completed.
content.formatted_body: If the iterator were a database, I would expect take to close the connection when completed.

content.body: * If the iterator were backed by a database, I would expect `take` to close the connection when completed.
content.formatted_body: * If the iterator were backed by a database, I would expect take to close the connection when completed.

m.new_content.body: If the iterator were backed by a database, I would expect `take` to close the connection when completed.
m.new_content.formatted_body: If the iterator were backed by a database, I would expect take to close the connection when completed.

content.body: The alternative is resource starvation, which is a bad failure state.
If you want "consume X and not close", that operation is normally named something like `read` (at least, where IO is concerned)
content.formatted_body: If you want "consume X and not close", that operation is normally named something like read (at least, where IO is concerned)

content.body: My impression is that the use case in that issue was a misuse of the API. Perhaps `take` may seem confusing in a vacuum, but not with adequate context
content.formatted_body: My impression is that the use case in that issue was a misuse of the API. Perhaps take may seem confusing in a vacuum, but not with adequate context

content.body: Why is it "Speaker's summary of key points" rather than "summary of key points" in the notes?

Didn't get to it due to time, but there is precedence for a `preventClose`/`preventReturn` option on the web: `preventClose` on `ReadableStream.prototype.pipeTo` and `ReadableStream.prototype.pipeThrough`. I am not necessarily in favour of adding that - but if we did, people may already be familiar with the opt out behaviour.
content.formatted_body: Didn't get to it due to time, but there is precedence for a preventClose/preventReturn option on the web: preventClose on ReadableStream.prototype.pipeTo and ReadableStream.prototype.pipeThrough. I am not necessarily in favour of adding that - but if we did, people may already be familiar with the opt out behaviour.

content.body:
> <@littledan:matrix.org> Why is it "Speaker's summary of key points" rather than "summary of key points" in the notes?

I haven't really been seeing speakers fill this in; I think note-takers and the committee could fill it in as well
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @littledan:matrix.org
Why is it "Speaker's summary of key points" rather than "summary of key points" in the notes?
I haven't really been seeing speakers fill this in; I think note-takers and the committee could fill it in as well

content.body: It can be written by anyone so please change the title if you like.  The key is that the presenter ought to be at least approving the summary so that we have some kind of responsibility when distributing the load of writing these summaries.

The confusion is a consequence of choosing to build an API that is dependent on `Iterator` vs the notion of an iterable. As I understood it as the proposal was advancing, basing this on `iterator` meant we were in the realm of "one shot" or "single use" iterators, and that any kind of reusable iteration would rely on arrow functions. IIRC, all of the helper methods are exhaustive, either through repeated calls to `.next` or through the use of `.return`. I don't believe `.take` should be substantially different in this regard. I would much rather have an "opt-out" mechanism to avoid closing an iterator than breaking from the norm here.
content.formatted_body: The confusion is a consequence of choosing to build an API that is dependent on Iterator vs the notion of an iterable. As I understood it as the proposal was advancing, basing this on iterator meant we were in the realm of "one shot" or "single use" iterators, and that any kind of reusable iteration would rely on arrow functions. IIRC, all of the helper methods are exhaustive, either through repeated calls to .next or through the use of .return. I don't believe .take should be substantially different in this regard. I would much rather have an "opt-out" mechanism to avoid closing an iterator than breaking from the norm here.

content.body: Definitely agreed that `take` not exhausting is not an option
content.formatted_body: Definitely agreed that take not exhausting is not an option

content.body: the question was just whether a different name could lead people to correctly intuit the semantics
my intuition is no, unless the name is literally, like `takeAndThenClose`
content.formatted_body: my intuition is no, unless the name is literally, like takeAndThenClose

content.body: The alternative, `.limit`, only really makes sense for numeric arguments. It becomes much less clear if you later adopt something like `.limitWhile` (vs. `.takeWhile`).
content.formatted_body: The alternative, .limit, only really makes sense for numeric arguments. It becomes much less clear if you later adopt something like .limitWhile (vs. .takeWhile).

content.formatted_body: fun fact, Java has both limit and takeWhile

content.formatted_body: (and no take)

I am not necessarily in favour of adding that - but if we did, people may already be familiar with the opt out behaviour.

waldemar: the core confusion from me is why do you trust multiple implementations to be correct and interoperable here, if you don't trust the spec to be correct (because it's so tricky to get correct)?
content.formatted_body: waldemar: the core confusion from me is why do you trust multiple implementations to be correct and interoperable here, if you don't trust the spec to be correct (because it's so tricky to get correct)?

content.body: like my goal isn't _just_ a correct document, it's correct interopable implementations
content.formatted_body: like my goal isn't just a correct document, it's correct interopable implementations

content.body: shu: It sounds like you're trying to fit the spec around one possible (and pretty problematic) implementation. The spec should be implementation-agnostic about internal details.
in this case my understanding is that the bounds the champions are working to put in place are precisely so that it _is_ implementable with that technique
content.formatted_body: in this case my understanding is that the bounds the champions are working to put in place are precisely so that it is implementable with that technique

content.body: I'm also more interested in the ns vs Âµs question.
(also why is the 64+32 impl problematic?)

> <@waldemarh:matrix.org> I'm also more interested in the ns vs Âµs question.

I know that ptomato framed this as "for future discussion" but I don't see any arguments to switch to microseconds at this point.
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @waldemarh:matrix.org
I'm also more interested in the ns vs Âµs question.
I know that ptomato framed this as "for future discussion" but I don't see any arguments to switch to microseconds at this point.

content.body: Elementary math: 64+32 can implement integral counts of subseconds. This is obvious.
well, V8's position is still pro microseconds, but we won't block the proposal on it if implementation complexities and bad performance cliffs are addressed
Not obvious: spec that explicitly manages two integers implements integral counts of subseconds. It's easy to get carries and overflows wrong, and you can't tell without examining the entire spec.
i agree with you
what i don't get is, why do you think that trickiness is best left for implementations to all figure out via implication?
If you just want Âµs, then you can store durations in flat 64-bit integers and get a much more efficient implementation with a range of >500,000 years.
indeed! *i* just want us
content.formatted_body: indeed! i just want us

content.body: but v8 has not been able to convince the champion group

> <@waldemarh:matrix.org> If you just want Âµs, then you can store durations in flat 64-bit integers and get a much more efficient implementation with a range of >500,000 years.

Do we have any information that this difference in performance will be signficant? there's so much other stuff going on anyway
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @waldemarh:matrix.org
If you just want Âµs, then you can store durations in flat 64-bit integers and get a much more efficient implementation with a range of >500,000 years.
Do we have any information that this difference in performance will be signficant? there's so much other stuff going on anyway

content.body: it's a nuanced conversation that's hard to tease apart
it's not just absolute performance, it's the complexity around supporting optimized paths also
it's philosophical objection
Whether a difference in performance is significant depends on who is writing the benchmark â˜º
apaprocki has given examples of other systems that support ns that temporal might want to interface with, which i don't really get at all

ns are common enough nowadays that it seems it would be limiting use cases unnecessarily by limiting to Âµs, e.g. node embeds v8 and would hopefully like to represent filesystem times without losing precision
those other systems don't have ns as part of a date-time arithmetic library, they're raw ns counts
they're int64s
what i'm saying is it doesn't follow "ns are common enough -> ns need ot be supported in a fully featured date-time arithmetic library"
you still can just put the raw ns count into a BigInt

V8 position is:

- ideal: us precision, simple bounded arithmetic + storage follows straightforwardly
- can live with: ns precision, with 64+32 being a tried-and-proven implementation technique from e.g. abseil that we can use
- cannot live with: ns precision, bigint math required
content.formatted_body:
V8 position is:

  • ideal: us precision, simple bounded arithmetic + storage follows straightforwardly
  • can live with: ns precision, with 64+32 being a tried-and-proven implementation technique from e.g. abseil that we can use
  • cannot live with: ns precision, bigint math required

I think using ns would create somewhat of a risk, that Temporal might become obsolete (which is a surprising choice given how much else we decided to be super future-proof for). It's sort of clear that we don't really need to go more precise than ns.

BTW here are my conclusion notes for the await using topic, please edit in the notes if you want to make changes:

### Summary
Various grammars for async resource disposal were considered, including results from polls. The champion's preference became `await using`, and several delegates were swayed to prefer this option based on the data and arguments presented.
There are concerns about the parse-ability of `await using`, both based on practical implementations and the fit into the ES spec's cover grammars; it's unclear if certain edge cases will be easy to manage.
If `await using` isn't viable, it's likely that `async using` isn't viable, and the committee may come back to the conclusion of `using await`, but this will need to come back to plenary for future discussion.

### Conclusion

The committee resolves to attempt the syntax `await using`.
The grammar will need to be worked out in a PR, which will need to be presented in a future plenary for review and consensus.
content.formatted_body:
BTW here are my conclusion notes for the await using topic, please edit in the notes if you want to make changes:

Summary

Various grammars for async resource disposal were considered, including results from polls. The champion's preference became await using, and several delegates were swayed to prefer this option based on the data and arguments presented.
There are concerns about the parse-ability of await using, both based on practical implementations and the fit into the ES spec's cover grammars; it's unclear if certain edge cases will be easy to manage.
If await using isn't viable, it's likely that async using isn't viable, and the committee may come back to the conclusion of using await, but this will need to come back to plenary for future discussion.

Conclusion

The committee resolves to attempt the syntax await using.
The grammar will need to be worked out in a PR, which will need to be presented in a future plenary for review and consensus.

content.body: Hey all, Ron (rbuckton ) and I will be requesting a new agenda item this Thursday which will propose the preferred `await using` syntax for the [Async Explicit Resource Management proposal](https://github.com/tc39/proposal-async-explicit-resource-management). We're currently working on the grammar, but will let everyone know when the slides and changes are ready to review.
